conclusion: To determine the temperature at state C, we need to analyze the given information and use the properties of an ideal gas.
State A has pressure \( p_0 \) and volume \( V_0 \). State C has pressure \( 0.6p_0 \) and volume \( 0.5V_0 \).
The ideal gas law is given by: \( PV = nRT \).
Relate the temperatures using the ideal gas law for state A: \( p_0 V_0 = n R T_0 \).
Relate the temperatures using the ideal gas law for state C: \( 0.6p_0 \cdot 0.5V_0 = n R T_C \).
Simplify the equation for state C: \( 0.3p_0 V_0 = n R T_C \).
Compare the equations from state A and state C.
Set up the ratio of the two equations: \( \frac{0.3p_0 V_0}{p_0 V_0} = \frac{n R T_C}{n R T_0} \).
The temperature at state C is \( \boxed{0.3 T_0} \).
